sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1: What is the Ramsey number R(3,4) for a complete graph where every two vertices are connected by an edge and it is required to have a red or blue color assigned to each edge?
message_2:
The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the smallest integer R such that any graph of order R (i.e., having R vertices) with its edges colored either red or blue will contain either a red subgraph of order m or a blue subgraph of order n.

In this case, we want to find the Ramsey number R(3, 4), which means we want to find the smallest integer R such that any graph of order R with its edges colored either red or blue will contain either a red triangle (a complete subgraph of order 3) or a blue complete subgraph of order 4.

The Ramsey number R(3, 4) is known to be 9. This means that in any graph with 9 vertices and its edges colored either red or blue, there will always be either a red triangle or a blue complete subgraph of order 4.
